utterances.sentences: Yes, I think everyone does that, Juan. I can't believe they give me a knife for this segment. They actually thought that was a good idea. Holding a knife on live television.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It will be Jesse and knife. Someone take this away from me. Dagen what do you think about the pineapple.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Don't give it to me ever. Pineapple, you're not allowed to eat in my house because it gets everything sticky. The handle on the refrigerator gets sticky. The door knobs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's good to eat--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Toilet and everywhere, everything is--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And it's good with vodka. Did you ever have the VIPs across the street?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I never had.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What isn't though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Delicious.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Are you a VIP across--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. Yes. Up next, it's one of the most heated debates in America, mayo or mustard on your sandwich. Well now you can have both. So, Heinz created a new product MAYOMUST, which combines them both. They also have MAYOCUE, which is mayonnaise and--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Barbecue sauce?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And MAYOCHUP, which I believe is mayonnaise and ketchup.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I'm mad because Heinz, I had this idea years ago and you guys ripped it off. I should get that lawyer from Sandmann to represent me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, you know I came up with something called Mayo Maroon 5 where you just take a Maroon 5 CD and just squirt mayonnaise all over it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They should have done that at halftime.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think this is great. I can't believe we haven't done this before. I especially like the MAYOMUST, because I like mayonnaise and mustard and this means less plastic, right, it's by one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh! thanks AOC.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The problem with this idea is--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No one's even eating them though. You say you like it--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I have to go to Pilates.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Pilates.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's the point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do it in mayo. Mayo Pilates.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, the problem with ketchup is it has so much sugar in it. Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It does?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So then like doctors will tell you, use mayo. But now, if you put - if you use mustard I mean. Now, if you put mayonnaise with the mustard, mayonnaise has a ton of fat.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: What doctors is telling you not to eat ketchup. Don't we have a lot more problems in life than--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No ketchup.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's all bad news about pineapples and the sugar.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I love pineapple.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. I'm going to try the MAYOCHUP. For those of you out there, this is ketchup and mayonnaise.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Do you like it? You have One More Thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And finally, a sweet story of the son helping his dad with his new business. The son posting this tweet saying, "my dad is sad, because no one's coming to his new donut shop." He also included a photo of the empty parking lot and posted the address of the shop. And the tweet went viral. By the next day, Billy's Donuts was completely sold out. Now, I have a theory Greg, you probably think this is fake.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I knew it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because I'll tell you, I fell for it. So, like the first person that I saw was Jake Tapper tweeted it and I was drinking, I think, and I was like - and I was out - and I was going, this is great. And it's one of those things where you feel good doing something without doing anything. So, I just retweeted it and that will help. And then also just 9,000 retweets and then you see, this is a brilliant marketing promotion because it doesn't feel like marketing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It feels totally like normal and nice. It's cute, but I feel like it might have been devious marketing. You can't do it again though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But so, you don't think this guy's actually selling donuts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think he's an automaton.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think it was great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A robot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Use whatever you have.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, like if Twitter is a thing you can use, and it doesn't cost you anything and now and everybody knows about this donut shop. I'm for it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait a second. Why would the guy not be selling donuts?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because Greg has a conspiracy theory like this is so shady. I thought maybe he thought he was trafficking in drugs or something.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was thinking--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You just think it's a cheap trick.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I think it's brilliant. I fell for it. Well, I think it's brilliant. And I also love donuts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I love donuts. I wear Homer Simpson T-shirts that say if donuts we truck. I think - what was that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: L.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Believe me, I get them all over. Your kitchen handles and bathroom, they would be a mess--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Good jelly donut with squirts out in your face.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Remember that as Dana pointed out last week, Kraft was having trouble selling their goods. And then they created the throw the cheese at the babies. And now, they're coming up with these crazy flavors.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh! You think this is a gimmick.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, if he's taking the donut guy--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm buying that, but you guys can't visit me this summer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The donut guys was gimmick. This is a gimmick.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can take it home, okay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Pineapples and beans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh! Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can take it home. Even the MAYOCUE, which barbecue and mayonnaise, and those of you who don't know that. One More Thing is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. It's time for One More Thing, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm so excited. Look what we have here. Yes. We've got new stuff for the cat. All right, first cat. This is great. The cat does what we're talking about the cheese challenge. Look at that. I don't even know if that's a nice thing to do with a cat. I have mixed feelings about that.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Like animals' cruelty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You can't eat that cheese, it's got cat hair. Let's go to the next one. This is just a kitten playfully biting this guy's hand. I'm not going to have any editorial judgment on this. I think this is perverse, but it's an adorable kitten. Look at that. And then the last one, you'll love this one. Very artistic. Look at that. Amazing, how high they can get up there. You know, it's incredible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, Jordan--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Look at that. Shall we vote. Is it cat number one with the cheese? Was it the fondly kitten or was it the leaping cat? Dagen?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to have to go with 1.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to - well it's 3-1. I was going to go with 1.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Well done. All right, I'm going to go next here. You know I've talked about Mercy Ships before. This is a surgical hospital ship that serves West Coast of Africa. Does amazing work. So, there is a film. No, don't make fun. This is up to South by Southwest and it's the first Oculus VR for good. Right. So, they went - and you can see this trailer. Take a listen. So, this is the first time they've done. Mercy Ships of course they provided her the free health care life changing surgery. And it's a real virtual reality experience that you can see if you go to mercyships.org, you can learn more and check out that film, it's going to be great. Juan, you're next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. He's not Rudolph, the red nosed reindeer, but the nose on this Meola, type of antelope at the Pittsburgh Zoo. No doubt changed colors when he fell through the ice on Saturday. The good news is a real hero showed up to save him. Take a look. You may not have heard it, but out there, there is applause from zoo visitors as rescue is taking place in these icy waters urging the animal out. The zookeeper says that the zoo I should say says the keeper was not injured, but she does have a story and I imagine she's going to be the employee of the month, if not the employee of the year for getting that animal back on land. Meanwhile, Fox News I think it's Jesse Watters is seeking an interview with the Meola.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We should give her the parking spot for a year, not the month. Okay, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dana, you know how people say soccer is for sissies.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh! I know what you're going to show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's not. People say, it's not a contact sport. Check out this guy. Oh! My God. Fan runs onto the pitch. They call it pitch, I believe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And just whacks this guy from behind, total cheap shot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's a real son of a pitch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Son of a pitch. That guy is right. And you know what, he was sentenced to 14 weeks in prison. Can't attend another soccer match in the UK for 10 years.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: That's terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what you get.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a long time in jail.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Also, if you guys ever looking for great breakfast, in Florida, especially on the East Coast, maybe if you're in Lantana, Florida, go to Dune Deck Cafe, best breakfast ever and they let you tear the pineapple apart with your bare hands. Honestly, the best breakfast of all-time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Dagen?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: This one is for you, Dana. Megan and Stephen Long launched a line of beer for dogs, it's called Good Boy Dog Beer. They started brewing the drink to help one of their dogs who had some health problems. Bone broth, fruit, vegetables, herbs and spices. Humans can drink it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is there alcohol?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What's the point?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: No alcohol. Sadly. So, your dog can feel more like connected to your own life, Greg. So, these are--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dog one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Innovation.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Session swirl mailman - mailman malt liquor, IPA a lot in the yard. Sniffing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Dagen, that was a great one. All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Dagen McDowell, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." President Trump kicking of a new showdown with Congress today by releasing his fiscal 2020 budget plan and requesting over $8 billion more in border wall funding. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders earlier, today, addressing the president's national security approach to securing the border.

utterances.speaker: SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: He's doing his job.  He's doing what Congress should be doing. He took an oath of office, and he has a constitutional duty to protect the people of this country. We have a humanitarian and national security crisis at our border, and the president is doing his job in addressing it. He gave Congress a number of opportunities to actually address it and they failed to do so. So the president is taking his constitutional authority that Congress granted him. Let's not forget the only reason he has authority to call a national emergency is because Congress gave them the right to do so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sanders also addressing a question of whether or not Mexico will be paying for the wall.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Is there anything in the president's 2020 budget request that has Mexico paying for the wall.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: As the president has stated a number of times, through the U.S. MCA trade deal that we look forward to getting past soon, that will be part of how that takes place.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer offering a joint statement saying Trump's call for the additional border wall funding will be dead on arrival. The president tweeting today, the Republican have a, quote, very easy vote this week, regarding his national security declaration, and telling them to, quote, get tough. OK.  So, Greg, a budget takes months to prepare --

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and two minutes to say it's dead on arrival.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. This is -- we've been through this for decades. It's not Trumpian. It's a Republican-Democratic dance. What does Republican do?  You cut government programs, you increased military spending, and then the Democrats say it's dead. But I have -- can I bring up the Greg theory?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. I've said this for -- the budget adds 1.1 trillion this year and then 1 trillion for the next three years, it's $4.1 trillion to the deficit. So it's adding 4 -- I'm sorry, it's adding 4.1 trillion to the debt, that's 1.1 trillion per year deficit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But do I do that correctly?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Dagen?

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. So if the government collects $3.7 trillion in taxes on average this year, why don't we just make the deal that we don't collect any taxes, right? We all get to keep our entire paychecks for a year and we pledge that we won't spend any more money than we can for four years.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Greg for president everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How about -- I mean, the fact --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait, what does that mean? We can spend --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We'll only be 3.7 trillion in debt instead of 4.1 trillion.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you just won Iowa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Because -- I mean, if we don't care --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Onto New Hampshire.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- if we don't care about the debt or the deficit, then let's not pay taxes for a year. And then we promised to keep -- we won't spend any - - we won't have any spending increases for four years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Dagen, how do the markets --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to make this interesting you guys. This is boring stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have some good stuff coming up, but how did that markets react?  No big deal?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: No big deal because this is not going anywhere. But, again, this is the big problem with this budget and politics in general. Nobody cares that the debt is going up. Democrats now are trying to make an issue out of it, which is just horse hooey that they're trying to talk about the -- wringing their hands and getting their trousers in a twist over the debt and the deficit. But the Republicans don't care about it either --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Some economists are saying it's not -- they're not as worried about it --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- said that. He said if you can borrow at these low, low, low, low, low rates and then we can invest it and make a better return on it, which just seems -- makes my head spin. Because, again, the day -- the days is going to come where we can't borrow at less than 2.7 percent a year over ten years. We might wake up one morning and it's 4 percent or 5 percent. By the way, the interest on the national debt is going to top what we spend on defense spending in just a few years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, did you love budget day or hate budget day when you work at the Washington Post?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I hate it because it could get complex. And the numbers -- you've got to add up the numbers, and then someone always complains about the way you added the numbers. They view the numbers --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I used to avoid budget day at all cost.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's craziness. And people take it quite seriously, even though, as you guys rightly say, it's dead on arrival. It is seen as a statement of the president's priorities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And it is definitely a political document in terms of what it says to his followers, which is why I disagree with you, Dagen. I think when Democrats complain about deficits now, it's not so much to say, oh, you know, you guys -- you drove up your own deficits in your time, and therefore your complaints are -- what do you say? House pop or something?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: That's me to not curse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, OK. But I think that the irony here is that Republicans have a long legacy of saying deficits matter. And so, suddenly now, with this president and with the -- oh, you know what -- we didn't say that. We didn't mean it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, do you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm about to say something I never thought I'd say. Juan's right. Republicans don't care about budget deficits. They don't care about the debt anymore. Both parties don't care about it. It's just a merry-go-round of insanity. This is dead on arrival, as everybody says.  This is just his wish list. But I like the priority to put that much money for the border wall. And if he had stuck with the $20 or $25 billion big ask that he had at the beginning, he would have been able to negotiate for a more of a position of strength, the art of the deal. Why am I telling the president about the art of the deal?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go big or go low.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So I have another layer to this which I think you're going to like more to talk about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's about impeachment or not impeachment, according to Nancy Pelosi. So she just did an interview today in which she said this, I'm not for impeachment. This is news. I'm going to give you some news right now, because I haven't said this to any press person before. But since you asked and I've been thinking about this, impeachment is so divisive to the country that unless there's something so compelling and overwhelming and bipartisan, I don't think we should go down that path because it divides the country, and he's just not worth it. So setting aside that last dig on he's not just worth it, no impeachment?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's a smart cookie if I can still say that in this era. She knows impeachment will do three things. It will bring up the best in Trump because he seems to rebound for antagonist --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Likes to fight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he likes to fight. Two, it will generate sympathy and anger and turn him into a folk hero, which is why he might even like the impeachment process because look what it did to Bill Clinton. Three, it handicaps the Dems because they spreads themselves too thin. They should be trying to win instead of trying to impeach. They've got two years to figure this thing out and she's saying, look, you know, you try to win an election, stop chasing this guy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Juan, you think she's trying to send a message to the rank and file that we're going to focus on governing until we have -- she said if it was compelling, overwhelming, and bipartisan, then we would do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. But I think that what she's saying is, in fact, Dana, a lot of the requests for, for example, material information from the White House, a lot of the continuing investigations that are going on, she's saying let's put our money on that as part of the 2020 effort because, basically, what you're going to see is there're going to say, hey, this is still a problem for President Trump. Why put ourselves in the way of President Trump's arrows in terms of saying impeachment. These people just -- are trying to undo the 2016 election.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think? She's trying to help the Democrats, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It helps the Democrats and it helps the country. And rarely do those things coexist equally because it will divide the country if it's not an overwhelming high crime and misdemeanor. And if the Democrats overreach and impeach on something as partisan as, you know, his taxes or something like that, or Stormy Daniels, you're going to see huge backlash. And she's not going to have a gavel for that long. I'm not saying she's old. She's seasoned. She's seen this before.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's wise.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's very wise. You can have these house things flip in a heartbeat on war, on corruption, and on overreach. And remember, it's the last time the Democrats overreached on Obamacare, they lost the House --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I remember that. Dagen, last word?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: This is why the Democrats took the House back because she sent this message out to them long before people went to the polls in November.  If you go back and look at the messaging, she said cut it with the impeachment talk. And then she can let Jerry Nadler and Adam Schiff and do whatever they want to about document requests and calling --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- they would not be uttering that word.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, well, we'll see what happens. OK, up next, watch this.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), MASSACHUSETTS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's just wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It was the it place to be for Democrats this weekend, 2020 contenders along with the parties most popular newcomers, all flocking to the south by southwest festival in Austin, Texas. While there, they were pushing progressive ideology and also taking shots at each other.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: This idea of like 10 percent better from garbage is -- shouldn't be what we settle for.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.utterance: Bernie has to speak to what Democratic socialism is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You are not one.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: I'm not. Break those things apart and we will have a more competitive, robust market in America. That's how capitalism should work.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Let's call it American capitalism for lack of a better word. It's not providing middle-class people and poor people the security or the opportunity that it used to.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I believe that we need to ask a lot more of people at the top in this country.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We have to make defeating climate change the number one priority of the United States.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: When I see the corrosive divide, and instead of trying to find ways to bring us together in times of crisis, he finds ways to bring us apart. This is Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You heard Elizabeth Warren there trying to separate herself from the growing support in the Democratic Party for socialist ideas. That may be the wrong move. A new poll finds that young voters are actually embracing the socialism agenda. And as for Bernie Sanders, well, he was a no-show. Instead, choosing to campaign in Iowa this weekend where he and potential 2020 contender Joe Biden are currently in the lead in the latest polling. Jesse, I think you're the youngest person at the table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: (clears throat)

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, sorry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe youngest at heart.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Didn't say shortest, he said youngest.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So here we have, you know, Generation Z, and Generation Z for the viewers is people who are aged 3 to 23, Millennials 24 to 38. And here's what interesting to them, for Generation Z, the youngest people, mass shootings, racial equality, immigration. For Millennials, health care, global warming, and mass shootings. How do you fit into this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't fit into it because I'm Generation X. I don't even know what we stand for. Does anybody know what we stand for?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah. So Generation X, again, for the viewers, 39 to 53, and you care about health care, terrorism, national security, and, you're going to like this, Dagen, the debt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, count me out of the debt then. But I definitely care about national security and health care. I don't know why these people don't understand what capitalism is and the difference between capitalism and socialism. I just have to maybe get back up out on the street and start educating them like I used too. It's probably because I've left the street. People don't understand what south by southwest is. It's like a capitalism orgy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You have people and companies flying in from all over the world, driving-in in their gas guzzling cars to exchange ideas, to sell music, to sell products, to sell technology, and then everybody is coming there to bash capitalism? It doesn't make much sense to me. I remember interviewing a young woman who was there and she was dressed up as Little Bo Peep. And she had a pacifier and her face was painted and she had pink hair. And I've said what do you think about Trump? And she goes I think Trump is crazy. And I'm looking at her and she's dressed up like this and I think, you think Trump is crazy and you look like that? That's why the irony is lost on these people. The Democrats are so smart, they think, that they're not self-aware to go and to bash capitalism in a place like this, I really don't understand it. One of the reasons Sanders -- excuse me, Elizabeth Warren is trying to distance herself from socialism, her negatives are at a 20 percent right now, unfavorable rating.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People really don't like her very much.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But Sanders is doing so much better than her in the polls and he is talking about socialism.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true. And you know what's also interesting, from this color-coded chart, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I was very impress.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That 30 percent to 50 percent have no idea or have no opinion of Warren, Kamala Harris, Beto O'Rourke, or Cory Booker. These people are undefined.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's early yet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Dana, let me just say the Generation Z folks, and again those are 3 to 23 year olds, have a positive view of socialism, don't see that there's any stigma attached to being called a socialist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think -- I'm wondering -- and I don't know a lot about this because, of course, I never rebelled against my parents. But it's a thing to rebel against your parents, right? So -- like to be -- to say you're socialist and to wear it proudly is like basically poking your parents in the eye. And it's -- when you're 3 to 23, I'm not going to put a lot of stock in that, but I do think that -- they -- when they see conservatives making fun of them for saying socialism is good, it makes them embrace it more. No matter what it means.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So should we stop making fun of them?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I think what Warren is talking about, she wants a refined and improved capitalism, whatever that means. So I take a look at this piece that was written about her -- Warren put out this big thing about breaking up the tech companies, like, I'm sorry, the government is now here to help?  Because one of the things -- so she has this arbitrary number that if a company got to $25 billion valuation, they would have to be broken up. And then she's complaining about -- the fact that Facebook bought Instagram and that's stifling competition. Like -- is anyone -- does anyone feel stifled about posting on social media? I don't think anyone feel stifled.  So, I think that that's where she's headed, but conservatives have got to take this seriously.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Dagen, 37 percent of the electorate in 2020 will be Generation Z and Millennials. That's a big chunk who are supporters of greater socialism-type policies.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And I don't care if you're 18 or 80, you can smell a phony 5 miles away, and that is what Elizabeth Warren's problem is. You see it in those negative -- because she says she's not a socialist or whatever, Democratic socialist. Her wealth program to basically reclaim wealth in this country, confiscate wealth, is as socialist as you are going to get.  It didn't even work in France, for God's sakes. And this is her big idea, other than breaking up the tech companies, which, by the way, is not that out there. There are a lot of people, right or left, who think that they've gotten too big. But to say that you're going to confiscate people's money just because they earned that money and have that money, it's not an income tax. It's not a tax on spending or behavior. It is literally the government going in your bank and taking your money. She's a socialist and she's annoying and that's why her negatives are bad.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Greg, I give you an opportunity now to attack older white males. Biden and Sanders in the lead in Iowa, Biden, 27 points, Sanders, 25, nobody else is close.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Together they're over 300 years old. I don't know. You know, I have to say -- OK, number one, socialism is, as I've said, the Freddy Krueger of ideologies, every decade it comes back, kills a bunch of people, and then we forget about it. And because these young people, Generation Z as they're called, are coming from the campus where the cultists, or the professors, refused to expose the evils of their religion which is socialism. However, we've got to talk about south by southwest because we're letting them off the hook here. How do you know south by southwest is over? When CNN is there. What CNN is doing a trivia contest. That's how you know when you quit pot is when your parents started up. All right, when your parents are going to south by southwest and doing trivia contest, you're no longer edgy. What would have been edgy is if somebody held a socialist happy hour there. You open up the bar, free bar, but behind there have a live feed of Venezuela of all the looting, the lack of electricity, the power outages. Oh, you can have your free beer, socialist, but this is what you're ideologies are causing. That would have been edgy and unusual in south by southwest. But instead --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You should do a pop-up next season.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to do a pop-up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why doesn't THE FIVE go next year?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That is something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's conspicuous consumption disguise as virtue signaling. And it's like watching your grandparents get high, which is not a bad thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway, apologies to Antonio, my son, who led a session at south by southwest.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's got to go Marfa. Go to Marfa.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. (INAUDIBLE) turns dangerous when a woman tries to get in a picture with a jaguar? Yeah, I said a jaguar. Stay with THE FIVE to see this one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Taking a selfie with a jaguar, the cat, not the car. That's what experts would call a bad idea, right up there with chugging tie pods or sitting behind Brian Stelter at a chili cook off. But in this era where people risk losing an arm for the likes, why the hell not? Over the weekend, a woman jumped a barrier at the Wildlife World Zoo in Arizona, to get a photo of the big cat, which then attacked. The woman's arm was torn open. The ugliness caught on a cell phone, of course. I watched it six times.  She has since apologized to the zoo, saying it was her fault. That's good.  The story was viewed by zillions because they're just like me, gross. But in this case, it's a good thing for it reminds people of a few lessons, talking about the video, not the attack. Although humans are animals, animals are not humans, yet we are fooled by their adorable faces to think they share our qualities that they like us, understand us, and enjoy our taste in turquoise jewelry.  Not so. Given the chance that these will tear you to shreds. Don't worry it's not personal. Two, we care about being liked, or likes. When we see something appealing, we imagine showing it to other people. So rather than enjoying the moment, a sunset, a waterfall, a deadly cat, we must get a better, closer picture.  It's sad. People are dying for attention, literally. So here's a rare case where social media can offer lessons that if we were to learn and reality would kill us. Finally, a cat video with a purpose. So, Dana, I respect a lady because she apologized. I bet she kind of realized if the dog -- the jaguar -- the dog? The jaguar might be in danger.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right, and that's the thing about this which is that we have to have more respect for these animals. Number one, they're already in captivity. They're in captivity so that we can learn about them and be better stewards of them because, as humans, we have dominion over the animals. And so we have to take better care of them. And the jaguar felt threatened when she got into his cage. So, of course, that was going to happen. I do think that it's good that she went back.  She must have been mortified. But if the jaguar had to be put down because of her selfishness of trying to get a selfie in the cage, then, obviously, that would have been something --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what you meant when you said the jaguar might be in danger.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it might have happened before too, Juan.. They do say that -- I think selfie-caused deaths are up to 93 in 2017. It was three in 2011. But I bet there's more because -- you know, if you get hit by a car or something and you drop your phone, how do you know?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: A lot of falling off cliffs, I think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Last week we had a woman hanging off a train.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Listen, I -- it takes me like five hours to Photoshop any selfie that I take, number one. I finally figured out how to, like, make my -- you know, give myself some cheekbones and make my thighs look smaller, number one. Number two, I can't go down an escalator without tripping and busting my chin wide open. So I don't understand -- I mean, it's obviously dangerous in more ways than we're even seeing here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, we are not enjoying moments. Like we're missing the big picture by trying to get the little picture --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I was in a museum yesterday and they had a whole exhibit of people taking pictures, selfies of themselves, because they say we've never had such easy access to photography in --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- the life of the world -- in the history of the world, right?  But to my mind, what this is is all about vainglory. I mean, it's all about you in a certain place and then you post it on Facebook or some other place, and it's really not about illuminating anything. It's just saying I was there. Oh, I was there. I was there. And I didn't just get a t- shirt, I got this lousy picture, and I might have died.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. You know what's funny, Jesse, is that -- even though everybody has a camera now, we don't have any more pictures of UFO's. Is that weird?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think they'll be all over the place.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think there's still life out there somewhere. If she'd pulled it off, it would have been an amazing selfie. I do understand what she was going for, a jaguar at a zoo. I mean millions and millions of likes. I get it. But to your point earlier, it's like more important to be on social media than to be in real life. And if you ever see pictures of concerts and instead of people enjoying the concerts, there is hundred thousand with their phones in the air.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What is that--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, it's like - wait a second, you're enjoying the concert, you're paying all this money, so you can watch it later. I think that's what the memory is for.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, and I don't think anyone watches it later either.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they don't watch it later.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I never do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe like maybe on the ride home.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: You won't enjoy the concert if I'm there. If you put your phone up like that, because I'm smacking it out of your hand.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But there is so many people doing that. So many people do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. And don't tempt fate, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Don't--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Animals are wild.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great. They're wild, exactly. I keep thinking I'm building up some kind of bank account with the animals, but maybe not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No,

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You first.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. The Covington High School student who faced off with a Native American activist is suing the media again. We'll tell you who and why, next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Crazy people. The Covington High School student who was the center of a confrontation with a Native American activist back in January is again going after the media. Fresh off the heels of a lawsuit filed last month against the Washington Post, the high schooler is now planning to sue CNN for more than $250 million. Here's his lawyer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: CNN was probably more vicious in its direct attacks on Nicholas than The Washington Post. Nicholas Sandmann did absolutely nothing wrong. CNN couldn't resist the idea that here is a guy with a - young boy with Make America Great Again cap on. So, they go after. They're out there right away going after this young boy and they maintain it for at least two days. Why didn't they stop and just take an hour and look through the Internet and find the truth and then reported, maybe do that before you report the lies.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Maybe do that before you report the lies. Greg, did they have a case?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know if they have a case, but the lawsuit is necessary because CNN is incapable of learning. They repeat the same mistakes which are these divisive efforts to cancel people out. If I were at CNN, if I was Jeff Zucker, I'd sit everybody down. Do you want to be part of this new trend of like basically publicly blacklisting people, ruining their lives, because if no one had put the brakes on this that kid's life would have been ruined? And anybody who happened to be a Trump supporter would be next. I mean consider how this would have turned out if there wasn't other video. CNN never would have taken a breath. They moved on from Covington to Smollett you know and they - even if you go back a few years, their anti- police narrative. They could have learned from that, but they didn't you know. And so, this banishment craze that they're on and what they could have done to this kid even if the lawsuit is without merit or whatever, maybe able to cause them to sit down and think about it. Just think about, do you want to be part of this mob, this new trend or do you want to actually sit back and think about what you're doing, because it's going to happen to you.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Dana, you're shaking your head?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm nodding, yes. I'm agreeing. The Washington Post was also sued by the same group before by on behalf of the young man and The Washington Post published an editorial - an editor's note I should say that said, we shouldn't have done that. We should have done more reporting. So, they're trying to at least address this so that when it does go in front of the judge and they might say there is no standing here and I don't know I'm with Greg, I don't know how it will turn out in court. But if they had not filed the lawsuit, nobody would be talking about this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Lawsuits drive coverage and news and even if they don't get $250 million from CNN or Washington Post or whatever, putting it out there for all of us to talk about is worthwhile.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And the money amounts are meant to send a message.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: To media organizations like your journalists shouldn't be belching bile on social media. Part of the mob, when they don't even know it's true. In the lawsuit that was filed against The Washington Post, Jesse. It says that one of the reporters there who wrote what worked on the story later retweeted that short video which basically told a story that was not true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm sure Zucker sent out a few memos telling everybody to check themselves on social media or else they're going to cost the company a fortune. I made a few gaffes in my career and CNN you know what they do, they point fingers and they laugh, and they mock. But you know what, at least I'm not responsible for a quarter of a billion-dollar lawsuit by smearing a minor. You know what, you guys are, not me. Also, CNN is pretty cocky. They're in third place. They - I think half the country thinks they're fake news and now they're facing a multi-million- dollar lawsuit. So, what they've done now and to Greg's point which I think is a great one. They now don't necessarily target popular people, famous people, talented politicians. They go after the little guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The woman that got the Russian bot or whatever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That she answered it and they cornered her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They go after anonymous people. They unmask random people. Remember the guy that did the funny video on YouTube of the body slam. They like put out his personal information. They go after minors. That's who they're really going after and that's bullying, and they always call out the bullies. They're the bullies.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Are the people over there want so irretrievably stupid that they don't know to take a breath. If you're going to go after a teenager, high school junior not a public figure, but a private figure with something if you don't know the whole story, you're just going to lambast this kid and try and destroy his life. Don't they have one breath of revelation that they shouldn't do that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just think this is a meritless lawsuit and I think this kid's being used by the right and I don't know who this lawyer is, but it sounds to me like there is a gravy train now. Washington Post, CNN, he's become a hero to people who associate this with any media injustice against the far right and against Trump supporters. But the key for me--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry, if CNN and all these news organizations did this to me and told a story about me, and basically rain hellfire down on me and my family and all of my buddies in school, my backside would be pretty chapped too to the tune of so far $0.5 billion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you wouldn't.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Oh! Yes. It would.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you what. I think if you felt that way Dagen, he would say, I want this over and I want people to know that they were wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, you get that Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Just give me a second. So, here's the thing. They didn't create this tape, this tape came from some body on the Internet that the government still doesn't know exactly who they are, but they could have been the Russians, whatever. They're tied to Brazil. That's the source of this tape. And then in this social media age when the tape gets out, everybody says, have you seen this tape. And then you get people like CNN and The Washington Post reacting to what--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: No, they were spreading it. That was my point. Real quick, final word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I don't know. I just don't - I don't think they learn, they don't have any external - the only external breaks you're going to have are from people like Nick Sandmann. That's the only way to the point. If you don't do this lawsuit people stop talking about it and they move on to the next outrage.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Amen. The viral video that proves you've been eating pineapple all wrong the whole time. That's next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Excellent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for the Fastest. First up, the Internet losing its mind over this viral video showing the right way to eat a pineapple. Apparently, we've been doing it completely wrong. You're supposed to pull it apart in chunks. So, Greg--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How you're - I don't know how--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The markup. Blamed the producer - you were once a producer, so you're just supposed to eat it up. You eat it up in chunks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why don't you try.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, like this was nature's idea, right, that you guys could be able to pull--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Silence.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is how, this is what I do when I'm at the - you know what, the worst way to eat pineapple on a pizza.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the way--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There we go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that a proper producer's--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is that proper.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Technique. Dana, if you ever had a part in your house and then Greg did that, I'd think you'd be offended.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. I have a pretty high tolerance for being offended by Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You should have heard what I said in the break.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know, you weren't offended then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I wish I would have known this. I also liked it when I learned how to eat a mango properly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's fun to learn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I was thinking that several years ago someone told me how you slice a mango and then you like create a checkerboard in the middle and then it all pops up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is not quite as good Jesse, but it's interesting because you know the difficult part about eating a pineapple is if you get the skin in your mouth, it can stick you. It can be put it out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think everyone does that, Juan. I can't believe they give me a knife for this segment. They actually thought that was a good idea. Holding a knife on live television.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It will be Jesse and knife. Someone take this away from me. Dagen what do you think about the pineapple.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Don't give it to me ever. Pineapple, you're not allowed to eat in my house because it gets everything sticky. The handle on the refrigerator gets sticky. The door knobs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's good to eat--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Toilet and everywhere, everything is--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it's good with vodka. Did you ever have the VIPs across the street?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I never had.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What isn't though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Delicious.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you a VIP across--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Yes. Up next, it's one of the most heated debates in America, mayo or mustard on your sandwich. Well now you can have both. So, Heinz created a new product MAYOMUST, which combines them both. They also have MAYOCUE, which is mayonnaise and--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Barbecue sauce?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And MAYOCHUP, which I believe is mayonnaise and ketchup.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
